The morning Sheila sprouted wings was the same morning Jerry Maddox bombed at the Comedy Cave for the third consecutive Tuesday. He'd been working on new material about airline food—fresh stuff, really cutting edge—when the screaming started outside. Through the brick walls of the club, muffled shrieks pierced the night like feedback through a cheap microphone.

"Tough crowd tonight," Jerry muttered to the bartender, who wasn't laughing either. Come to think of it, nobody had laughed at anything all week. The audiences just sat there, stone-faced, like they were waiting for something that never came. Jerry had been doing stand-up for eight years, ever since college, and he'd never seen crowds this dead.

The bartender, a thick-necked guy named Mike who usually appreciated Jerry's more colorful observations about city life, was staring at the television mounted above the bar. The sound was off, but the closed captions were running wild with breaking news alerts. Jerry squinted at the screen and saw footage of what looked like a woman floating three feet off the ground, massive white wings unfurled behind her like some kind of Victorian fever dream.

"You seeing this?" Mike asked, his voice carrying the kind of bewilderment usually reserved for tax audits and relationship advice.

Jerry walked closer to the screen, adjusting his thick-rimmed glasses. The woman on the news was definitely airborne, and those wings looked authentic—not like the costume shop variety he'd seen at Halloween parties. Real feathers caught the light as she moved, and her face held an expression of serene confusion, like she'd just discovered she could suddenly speak Mandarin.

"Special effects," Jerry said automatically. "Has to be. Probably some viral marketing thing for a new superhero movie."

But even as he said it, the explanation felt hollow. The newscast switched to another angle, then another. Different women, different locations, all sporting identical sets of pristine white wings. The reporter's voice was audible now as Mike fumbled for the volume control.

"—confirmed reports from seventeen major cities worldwide. The phenomenon appears to be affecting only women between the ages of sixteen and sixty-five. Medical experts are baffled, while religious leaders are calling it everything from divine intervention to—"

The front door of the Comedy Cave burst open with enough force to rattle the framed photographs of long-dead comedians on the walls. Sheila Martinez, Jerry's ex-girlfriend and current complicated-friendship-situation, stumbled inside. Her hair was disheveled, her eyes were wide with panic, and sprouting from her shoulder blades were two enormous wings that scraped against the doorframe as she entered.

"Jerry!" she called out, spotting him near the bar. "Thank God you're here. I didn't know where else to go."

Jerry stared at her, his brain attempting to process the visual information while simultaneously rejecting it entirely. Sheila looked exactly like herself—same dark hair, same skeptical brown eyes, same tendency to bite her lower lip when nervous—except for the minor detail of the angelic appendages that made her look like she'd stepped out of a Renaissance painting.

"Okay," Jerry said slowly, "I'm going to need you to back up a little bit. Literally. Those things are knocking over chairs."

Sheila glanced behind her, where her wings had indeed swept several bar stools to the floor. She tried to fold them closer to her body, but the movement was clumsy and unfamiliar. "I don't know how to control them yet. They just... appeared. About two hours ago, right in the middle of my shift at the hospital."

"Your shift at the hospital," Jerry repeated. "Where you work as a nurse. A job that requires you to fit through normal-sized doorways."

"Jerry, this isn't the time for your comedy routine." Sheila managed to navigate around the scattered furniture and approached the bar, her wings now partially folded but still impressive in their scope. "Something is happening to women everywhere. Not just the wings—there's something else. I can... feel things differently. Like I'm connected to something bigger."

Mike the bartender had given up all pretense of casual interest and was openly gawking. "Can you fly?" he asked.

"I don't know," Sheila admitted. "I've been too scared to try. But I can feel that I could, if I wanted to. It's like having a muscle you never knew existed."

Jerry rubbed his temples, feeling the beginning of what promised to be an extraordinary headache. "Let me see if I understand this correctly. You're telling me that women around the world are spontaneously developing wings and mystical powers, and instead of going to the CDC or the National Guard or, I don't know, the Pope, you came to a failed comedian in a dive club."

"You're not a failed comedian," Sheila said automatically, then paused. "Well, okay, you're struggling. But you're also the smartest person I know when it comes to seeing through nonsense and getting to the truth of things. Plus, you have that weird ability to find patterns where other people see chaos."

This was true. Jerry had always been good at connecting seemingly unrelated dots, a skill that served him well both in constructing comedy routines and in his previous life as an investigative journalist. He'd left journalism after a story about municipal corruption had gotten buried by editors who preferred their news with less controversy and more celebrity gossip, but the instincts remained sharp.

"Alright," Jerry said, pulling out his phone. "Let's assume for the moment that this is real and not some kind of elaborate prank designed to make me question my sanity. What exactly do you want me to do about it?"

Before Sheila could answer, Jerry's phone buzzed with an incoming text from his neighbor, Mrs. Chen. The message was brief but concerning: "Emergency at building. Come home. Bring first aid."

Jerry showed the text to Sheila, whose newly enhanced intuition apparently extended to reading upside-down messages. Her face went pale. "Something's wrong," she said. "I can feel it. There's fear coming from that direction." She pointed toward Jerry's apartment building, which was six blocks away.

"You can feel fear from six blocks away?" Jerry asked.

"Apparently. Along with hope, anger, and what I think might be someone's intense craving for Chinese food." Sheila flexed her wings experimentally. "Jerry, I think we need to get over there. Fast."

Jerry looked at his ex-girlfriend, who now appeared to be some kind of supernatural being, then at Mike, who was still staring like he'd never seen wings before, then at the television, where the news was showing footage of winged women helping with disaster relief, traffic accidents, and what appeared to be a cat stuck in a tree.

"This is insane," Jerry muttered.

"Completely," Sheila agreed. "Are you in?"

Jerry considered his options. He could stay in the Comedy Cave, finish his drink, and pretend this was all an elaborate hallucination brought on by too much caffeine and career disappointment. Or he could follow his ex-girlfriend, who had apparently become an angel, into whatever crisis was waiting at his apartment building.

"I'm going to need something first," Jerry said, walking behind the bar.

"What kind of something?" Sheila asked, watching as Jerry rummaged through the storage area behind the beer taps.

"Aha!" Jerry emerged holding what appeared to be an ordinary office stapler, except that it was slightly larger than normal and had strange markings etched into its metallic surface. "Found it."

"You found a stapler," Sheila said. "In a bar."

"Not just any stapler," Jerry corrected, hefting the device in his hand. "This is Mike's infinite stapler. He uses it for putting up promotional flyers. Show her, Mike."

Mike nodded eagerly and grabbed a stack of paper from behind the register. Jerry took aim and fired the stapler at the wall. Instead of a normal stapling action, the device shot out a continuous stream of staples, creating a perfect line across the brick wall. He adjusted his grip and the stream changed direction, forming a crude smiley face pattern.

"It never runs out of staples," Mike explained. "I bought it from this weird guy at a flea market. He said it was cursed, but honestly, it's been great for advertising."

Jerry tucked the stapler into his jacket pocket. "If we're going to investigate supernatural phenomena, I want supernatural office supplies."

Sheila stared at him for a long moment, then burst out laughing. It was the first genuine laugh Jerry had heard all week, and it occurred to him that maybe his comedy wasn't the problem—maybe the world had just stopped being funny until this moment.

"Okay," she said, wiping tears from her eyes. "A nurse with wings and a comedian with an infinite stapler. This is either the beginning of the most ridiculous superhero team ever, or we're both having the same psychotic break."

"Either way," Jerry said, heading toward the door, "it beats my usual Tuesday night."

They stepped out into the street, where the scene was unlike anything Jerry had ever witnessed outside of disaster movies. Women with wings filled the sky like a flock of enormous birds, some flying with grace and purpose, others flapping uncertainly as they learned to navigate their new abilities. On the sidewalks, people stood in clusters, pointing and taking pictures, their faces reflecting mixtures of wonder, fear, and confusion.

"How are we getting to your building?" Sheila asked. "I could try flying, but I don't think I can carry you yet."

"We walk," Jerry said. "Like normal people. Well, like one normal person and one... what are you exactly now?"

"I have no idea," Sheila admitted. "But Jerry, I think this is just the beginning. Whatever's happening, it's bigger than just wings. I can feel something coming. Something that's going to change everything."

Jerry looked up at the sky, where silhouettes of winged women moved against the stars like a scene from mythology come to life. In his pocket, the infinite stapler felt warm and oddly comforting.

"Then we'd better figure out what we're dealing with," he said. "Before whatever's coming gets here."

They began walking toward Jerry's neighborhood, weaving between crowds of onlookers and news crews. Above them, the newly transformed women continued their aerial dance, and Jerry couldn't shake the feeling that the world had just shifted into a new gear—one that might be spinning too fast for anyone to control.

**Chapter 1**

Jerry's apartment building stood at the corner of Fifth and Morrison like a tired brick monument to urban decay. Under normal circumstances, the three-story structure was unremarkable except for its persistent plumbing issues and Mrs. Chen's habit of cooking fish at three in the morning. Tonight, however, the building was surrounded by what appeared to be half the city's emergency response teams, along with a growing crowd of civilians who had apparently decided that watching potential disasters unfold was preferable to staying home and pretending the world still made sense.

"Well, that's not ominous at all," Jerry muttered, taking in the scene of flashing lights and yellow police tape. Three fire trucks were parked haphazardly across the street, their crews standing around with the particular brand of purposeful confusion that suggested they'd been called to handle something outside their usual training parameters. Paramedics wheeled empty gurneys back and forth between ambulances, while police officers gestured at clipboards and spoke into radios with increasing urgency.

Sheila's wings twitched with what Jerry was beginning to recognize as her new supernatural anxiety response. "Something's definitely wrong. I'm getting waves of panic from inside the building, but also... something else. Something that feels almost like electricity, but not quite." She paused, tilting her head as if listening to a frequency only she could hear. "Jerry, I think there are more women in there who've changed like me, but they're not handling it as well."

They approached the police perimeter, where a young officer with the kind of mustache that suggested he took his authority very seriously was directing civilians to move along. Jerry recognized him as Officer Martinez—no relation to Sheila, despite the shared surname—who had once given Jerry a ticket for jaywalking while carrying a microphone stand. The officer's expression suggested he remembered the encounter as well.

"Building's closed, Maddox," Officer Martinez said, not looking up from his clipboard. "Emergency situation. You'll need to find somewhere else to bomb tonight." The joke fell flat, partly because Martinez delivered it with all the comedic timing of a tax return, but mostly because the screaming that had been audible from inside the Comedy Cave was now clearly coming from Jerry's building.

"I live here," Jerry pointed out, gesturing toward the third-floor windows of his apartment. "And this is Sheila Martinez, registered nurse." He deliberately avoided mentioning the wings, partly because they were currently folded against Sheila's back in a way that made them less immediately obvious, and partly because he suspected that introducing supernatural elements to this conversation would not improve their chances of getting inside.

Officer Martinez looked up from his paperwork and his eyes immediately locked onto Sheila's wings. His expression shifted through several distinct phases: confusion, recognition, disbelief, and finally what appeared to be the thousand-yard stare of someone whose worldview had just been thoroughly reorganized. "You're one of them," he said unnecessarily.

"One of the women with wings, yes," Sheila confirmed patiently. "Which is exactly why you should let us through. If there are others in there who are having trouble adjusting to their new situation, I might be able to help. I work in emergency medicine, and I understand what they're going through."

The screaming from inside the building reached a new pitch, accompanied by what sounded like breaking glass. Officer Martinez winced and spoke into his radio. "Control, this is Martinez. We've got another one out here, requesting entry to assist. She's... uh... she appears to be cooperative and medically trained." He paused, listening to the response through his earpiece, then looked back at Sheila. "They want to know if you can control your abilities."

"I can keep them folded and avoid knocking things over, if that's what they're asking," Sheila said. "But if someone in there needs help learning how to manage their wings, I'm probably the most qualified person you're going to find on short notice."

Another crash echoed from the building, followed by shouting voices and what Jerry could swear sounded like the splintering of wooden furniture. Officer Martinez made the kind of executive decision that would either earn him a commendation or a disciplinary hearing. "Alright, you can go in, but you're taking responsibility for anything that happens. And you," he pointed at Jerry, "stay with the medical personnel and don't touch anything."

They ducked under the yellow tape and approached the building's main entrance, where Jerry could see that the glass front door had been completely shattered. The lobby beyond was a chaos of scattered mail, overturned furniture, and what appeared to be several large holes in the drywall. Jerry's first thought was that someone had driven a small vehicle through the space; his second thought, as he took in the wing-shaped impressions in some of the holes, was considerably more unsettling.

"Mrs. Chen?" Jerry called out as they climbed the stairs toward the second floor, where the sounds of distress seemed to be concentrated. "Mrs. Chen, it's Jerry from upstairs! Are you okay?"

"Mr. Jerry!" Mrs. Chen's voice came from somewhere above them, tinged with her usual mixture of authority and exasperation. "Thank goodness you're here! Mrs. Patterson has become a bird, and she's very upset about it!"

They reached the second-floor landing to find Mrs. Chen standing outside apartment 2B, still wearing her floral print apron and holding a wooden spoon like a weapon. Despite being in her seventies and barely five feet tall, she radiated the kind of unflappable competence that had helped her manage the building's more eccentric tenants for the past fifteen years. Jerry noticed that she showed no signs of having sprouted wings herself, which raised interesting questions about the selection criteria for whatever was happening to women around the world.

"Mrs. Patterson?" Jerry asked, remembering his neighbor as a quiet accountant who worked from home and occasionally complained about noise from his comedy practice sessions. "She's the one screaming?"

"Not just screaming," Mrs. Chen corrected grimly. "Flying into walls. She got the wings about an hour ago, right in the middle of watching her evening programs, and she's been trying to escape through her windows ever since. The problem is that she keeps missing the windows and hitting everything else instead."

As if summoned by their conversation, another crash resonated from apartment 2B, accompanied by a voice Jerry recognized as Mrs. Patterson's shouting something that sounded like a creative mixture of accounting terminology and profanity. Sheila moved toward the door, her own wings instinctively spreading slightly as she prepared to enter what was clearly a crisis situation.

"Mrs. Patterson?" Sheila called through the door. "My name is Sheila Martinez. I'm a nurse, and I have wings too. Can I come in and help you?"

The crashing stopped abruptly, replaced by suspicious silence. Then Mrs. Patterson's voice, shaky but audible: "You have wings? Real wings? Not just saying that to make me feel better about losing my mind?"

"Real wings," Sheila confirmed. "I got them about three hours ago, and I nearly took out half a hospital supply closet before I figured out how to fold them properly. Mind if I come in and show you a few tricks?"

The door opened to reveal Mrs. Patterson, who normally appeared as a perfectly organized woman in her forties with an impressive collection of cardigans. Tonight, however, she looked like she'd been through a small hurricane. Her hair was disheveled, her clothes were torn in several places, and the wings sprouting from her back were significantly larger than Sheila's—easily eight feet from tip to tip when fully extended. Her living room behind her looked like a tornado had attempted to rearrange the furniture using only brute force and poor judgment.

"I can't control them," Mrs. Patterson said, her voice carrying the kind of barely contained panic that Jerry associated with people who had just discovered their tax returns had been audited. "Every time I try to move normally, they hit something. When I get frustrated, they spread out on their own. And when I tried to fly..." she gestured helplessly at a Mrs. Patterson-shaped hole in her bedroom wall that was visible through her open bedroom door.

Sheila nodded with the professional sympathy of someone who had spent years dealing with medical emergencies. "The first thing you need to know is that panic makes everything worse. The wings seem to respond to emotional states, so the more upset you get, the harder they are to control. Can you try taking a few deep breaths while I show you how to fold them close to your body?"

Jerry watched as Sheila demonstrated the wing-folding technique she'd been developing over the past few hours. It involved a specific sequence of muscle movements that looked completely unnatural to Jerry but seemed to make sense to Mrs. Patterson, whose own wings gradually settled into a more manageable position. The process took several minutes and involved what Jerry could only describe as supernatural physical therapy, but the results were immediately visible in the way Mrs. Patterson's posture relaxed.

"Better?" Sheila asked.

"Much better," Mrs. Patterson admitted. "But I still don't understand what's happening to me. To us. The news is saying it's some kind of worldwide phenomenon, but they don't have any explanations. Just speculation about everything from genetic mutations to divine intervention."

Jerry cleared his throat from his position near the door, where he'd been observing the wing-management lesson while simultaneously cataloging the damage to Mrs. Patterson's apartment for what promised to be fascinating insurance claims. "Actually, I might have some ideas about that. But first, I need to ask both of you something that might sound strange. Have either of you noticed any changes beyond just the physical wings? Enhanced senses, unusual intuitions, anything like that?"

Sheila and Mrs. Patterson exchanged glances, and Jerry could practically see them realizing that they'd both been experiencing something they hadn't yet put into words. Mrs. Patterson spoke first: "I've been feeling like I can sense things about people's emotional states. Not mind reading, exactly, but like I can tell when someone is lying or afraid or... I don't know how to describe it."

"And I've been getting what feel like directional impulses," Sheila added. "Like right now, I can feel that there's someone else in this building who needs help, somewhere above us. Not Mrs. Chen," she nodded toward their elderly landlord, "but someone else who's dealing with a situation similar to Mrs. Patterson's."

Jerry felt the infinite stapler in his pocket grow slightly warm, which struck him as either a very good sign or a very bad one. "Mrs. Chen, who else lives on the third floor besides me?"

Mrs. Chen consulted the mental inventory she maintained of all her tenants. "Just you and the new girl in 3A. Sarah something. Very quiet, works for one of those computer companies. Moved in about a month ago."

As if responding to their conversation, a sound echoed from the floor above them—not crashing or screaming like Mrs. Patterson's earlier distress, but something that sounded almost like singing. The melody was hauntingly beautiful but completely unfamiliar, carrying notes that seemed to resonate in frequencies that Jerry could feel in his chest rather than just hear with his ears.

"That's not normal singing," Mrs. Patterson observed with the matter-of-fact tone of someone whose definition of normal had been thoroughly revised over the past few hours.

"No," Sheila agreed, her wings twitching with what Jerry now recognized as her supernatural early warning system. "And whatever's happening up there, it's different from what happened to us. I can feel... power. Like she's not just growing into abilities, she's accessing something that was already there."

Jerry looked around at the group that had somehow formed around him: his ex-girlfriend who had become an angel, his neighbor who was learning to manage her new aerial capabilities, and his elderly landlord who seemed to be taking the entire supernatural crisis in stride. In his pocket, the infinite stapler continued to radiate warmth, and above them, the mysterious singing grew stronger and more complex.

"Right," Jerry said, making the kind of decision that would either lead to answers or get them all killed in interesting ways. "I think it's time we went upstairs and introduced ourselves to Sarah something. Because if tonight has taught me anything, it's that ignoring weird supernatural phenomena is probably not the best survival strategy."

They climbed toward the third floor, following the sound of otherworldly music and hoping that whatever they found there would provide some answers rather than just adding new questions to an already complicated situation.

**Chapter 2**

The third floor of Jerry's building had always been the quietest level, partly because it housed only two apartments and partly because Jerry had trained himself over the years to move through his daily routines with the stealth of someone who understood that thin walls and irritable neighbors were a dangerous combination. Tonight, however, the hallway thrummed with an energy that seemed to emanate from apartment 3A, where the mysterious Sarah's singing had evolved into something that defied easy categorization. The melody wove through harmonies that shouldn't have been possible for a single human voice, creating layers of sound that seemed to bend the air itself into new shapes.

Jerry paused outside his own apartment door, fishing for his keys with the automatic gesture of someone who had performed the same action thousands of times before. But as his hand touched the familiar metal, the infinite stapler in his pocket suddenly blazed with heat so intense that he jerked backward, nearly colliding with Mrs. Patterson's carefully folded wings. The stapler wasn't just warm anymore—it was practically vibrating with what felt like barely contained energy, as if it were responding to some kind of supernatural proximity alarm.

"Jerry?" Sheila asked, noticing his sudden movement. "What's wrong?"

"The stapler," Jerry said, pulling the device from his pocket. The ordinary-looking office tool was now glowing with a faint blue light that pulsed in rhythm with Sarah's singing. "I think it's reacting to whatever's happening next door. Which either means it's more magical than Mike let on, or we're about to encounter something that makes infinite office supplies seem perfectly reasonable by comparison."

Mrs. Chen examined the glowing stapler with the clinical interest of someone who had spent decades dealing with unusual tenant situations. "In my experience," she said thoughtfully, "when household objects start glowing blue, it usually means someone is practicing magic without proper permits. I'll need to check the lease agreements to see if supernatural activities require additional deposits."

The singing from apartment 3A reached a crescendo that seemed to vibrate through the building's foundation, and Jerry noticed that the overhead lights in the hallway had begun to flicker in complex patterns. Not the random electrical fluctuations of faulty wiring, but deliberate sequences that reminded him of morse code or some other form of systematic communication. Mrs. Patterson's wings spread involuntarily in response to the sound, and Jerry could see that Sheila was having to concentrate to keep her own wings folded as whatever power was emanating from Sarah's apartment grew stronger.

"We need to make contact," Sheila said, her voice tight with the effort of maintaining control over her supernatural appendages. "Whatever she's doing in there, I don't think she realizes how it's affecting the rest of us. And if this energy keeps building, we might have bigger problems than learning to manage wings."

Jerry approached the door to apartment 3A, noting that the wood around the frame had developed what appeared to be intricate patterns of frost, despite the fact that it was a warm Tuesday night in September. The singing beyond the door had taken on an almost hypnotic quality, and Jerry found that he had to shake his head periodically to maintain focus on their immediate situation rather than getting lost in the otherworldly melody.

"Sarah?" Jerry called out, knocking on the door with what he hoped was the right balance of friendliness and urgency. "This is Jerry from next door. Are you alright in there? We're getting some unusual energy readings out here, and we wanted to make sure everything was okay."

The singing stopped abruptly, replaced by a silence so complete that Jerry could hear his own heartbeat echoing in his ears. Then came the sound of footsteps—not ordinary footsteps, but something that seemed to include additional rhythmic elements, as if Sarah was moving with more limbs than standard human anatomy typically provided. The door opened to reveal a young woman in her mid-twenties with shoulder-length auburn hair and the kind of pale complexion that suggested she spent most of her time indoors. She was wearing jeans and a oversized sweater that had definitely not come from any normal clothing store, because Jerry could see that it had been modified to accommodate what appeared to be four additional arms sprouting from her torso.

"Oh," Sarah said, her voice carrying traces of the same otherworldly harmonics that had characterized her singing. "You're the comedian. I've heard you practicing through the walls. You're actually funnier than you think you are, but you've been trying too hard to appeal to audiences who aren't ready for your particular brand of observational humor." She paused, taking in the sight of Sheila's wings and Mrs. Patterson's barely controlled supernatural appendages. "And you're some of the other changed ones. I wondered when we'd start finding each other."

Jerry stared at Sarah's additional arms, which moved with a fluid grace that suggested she'd been managing them for longer than the few hours since the worldwide transformation had begun. Two of the extra limbs appeared to be holding what looked like glowing geometric shapes that pulsed with the same blue light as his stapler, while the others gestured expressively as she spoke, adding a visual component to her communication that was both mesmerizing and slightly disorienting.

"You seem remarkably well-adjusted to your situation," Mrs. Patterson observed, her accountant's instincts apparently extending to supernatural crisis management. "How long have you had the extra arms? And what were you doing that was affecting the building's electrical systems?"

Sarah smiled, and Jerry noticed that her teeth had developed an almost crystalline quality that caught and reflected light in ways that definitely weren't normal. "I didn't grow extra arms," she explained patiently. "I've always had them. Same with the singing that works with frequencies most people can't hear. What happened tonight wasn't that I changed—it's that whatever was hiding my real nature stopped working. And from what I can tell from the news reports and the energy patterns I'm sensing from around the city, the same thing is happening to women everywhere. We're not being transformed into something new. We're being revealed as what we always were underneath."

This statement landed in the hallway with the impact of a philosophical bombshell. Jerry felt his understanding of the evening's events undergo a fundamental reorganization as he considered the implications of Sarah's words. If she was correct, then the women weren't developing supernatural abilities—they were supernatural beings who had been disguised as ordinary humans, and something had just broken the disguise.

"That's impossible," Mrs. Patterson said automatically, then paused as she considered her own situation. "Although I suppose if someone had told me this morning that I'd be learning to fold wings by dinner time, I would have said that was impossible too. But if what you're saying is true, then what are we exactly? And why don't we remember being anything other than human?"

Sarah gestured for them to enter her apartment, and Jerry found himself in a living space that bore no resemblance to the standard layout he was familiar with from his own unit. The walls were covered with intricate diagrams that seemed to shift and change when he wasn't looking directly at them, and the furniture appeared to have been designed for someone with significantly more limbs than the average person. Crystals of various sizes and colors hung from the ceiling, casting patterns of light that created the impression of being inside some kind of mystical observatory.

"Memory modification is actually pretty standard procedure," Sarah explained, settling into what appeared to be a chair designed specifically for someone with six arms. "Think about it from a practical perspective. If you were going to hide supernatural beings in plain sight within human society, you'd need them to believe they were human too. Otherwise, maintaining the disguise would require constant conscious effort, and that would be exhausting and prone to failure."

Sheila moved carefully through the transformed apartment, her wings responding to the ambient magical energy by developing what Jerry could swear was a faint luminescence of their own. "So you're saying that somewhere in our suppressed memories, we know what we really are? And we know why we were hidden?"

"Exactly," Sarah confirmed, two of her extra hands continuing to manipulate the glowing geometric shapes while her original hands gestured expressively. "And I think I know what triggered the revelation tonight. Jerry, can I see that stapler you're carrying? I can feel it resonating with the same frequency as these focus crystals I've been working with."

Jerry handed over the infinite stapler, which had continued to glow with increasing intensity since they'd entered Sarah's apartment. As soon as the device made contact with Sarah's hands, the geometric shapes she'd been holding flared with brilliant light, and suddenly the apartment was filled with images that flickered through the air like three-dimensional holograms. Jerry saw glimpses of vast cities that bore no resemblance to human architecture, beings with wings and multiple limbs moving through spaces that seemed to exist in more than three dimensions, and what appeared to be some kind of cosmic conflict involving forces of light and shadow battling across landscapes that defied physics.

"A viewing focus," Sarah said with satisfaction as the images stabilized into something approaching coherence. "I've been trying to access the memory records for weeks, but I needed a properly calibrated mystical artifact to complete the connection. Where did you get this?"

"Mike at the Comedy Cave bought it from some guy at a flea market," Jerry said, watching as the holographic images resolved into what appeared to be a historical documentary about supernatural beings living in disguise among humans. "He thought it was cursed, but it just seemed to have unlimited staples."

Sarah laughed, a sound that harmonized with itself in ways that created music from what should have been ordinary human expression. "Of course it has unlimited staples. It's a manifestation focus designed to create matter from ambient mystical energy. Staples are just the simplest form of organized matter it can produce. But more importantly, it's been attuned to the same concealment network that's been hiding our true natures. When the network started failing tonight, artifacts like this began activating to help us recover our suppressed knowledge."

The holographic images shifted to show what appeared to be a great exodus, with thousands of winged and otherwise enhanced beings leaving vast supernatural cities and integrating themselves into human communities. The timeline suggested this had happened several decades ago, which raised uncomfortable questions about the childhoods and family histories that Jerry and the others believed they remembered.

"We're refugees," Mrs. Patterson said, her voice carrying the tone of someone whose orderly worldview had just been completely reorganized. "We fled from somewhere else and hid among humans for protection. But refugees from what?"

The holograms answered her question with images that made Jerry's blood run cold. Dark creatures that seemed to be composed of living shadow swept through the supernatural cities like a plague, corrupting everything they touched and transforming the mystical architecture into twisted parodies of its former beauty. The beings Jerry had seen fleeing in the earlier images weren't just leaving their homes—they were running for their lives from something that appeared to devour light itself.

"The Devourers," Sarah said quietly, her extra arms moving in complex patterns that Jerry realized were some kind of protective gesture. "They broke through from the shadow dimensions about fifty years ago and began consuming our realm piece by piece. Those of us who could escape came here, to the human world, and used concealment magic to hide among the population while we hoped our enemies would lose interest and move on to other dimensions."

Sheila's wings were now glowing with definite luminescence, and Jerry noticed that Mrs. Patterson's were beginning to show similar signs of supernatural activation. "But they didn't lose interest, did they?" Sheila asked. "Something's happened that's made hiding impossible, and that's why the concealment magic is failing."

The holographic display shifted to show current events, with images of the Earth surrounded by what appeared to be vast shadow constructs moving through space toward their planet. The estimated time of arrival, according to the mystical calculations floating beside the images, was approximately seventy-two hours.

"The Devourers found us," Sarah confirmed grimly. "Our concealment network detected their approach and began emergency protocols to restore our true abilities so we can defend ourselves and the humans we've been living among. What you're experiencing tonight isn't a supernatural phenomenon—it's a call to arms."

Jerry sank into one of Sarah's unusual chairs, his mind reeling as he tried to process the implications of what they'd just learned. According to the holographic evidence, he and possibly millions of other women around the world were actually supernatural refugees who had been living under magical disguises for decades. Their human memories, their families, their entire life histories might be elaborate fabrications designed to help them blend into human society. And now, ancient enemies were approaching Earth with the apparent intention of finishing the job they'd started in whatever dimension Jerry and the others had originally called home.

"Okay," Jerry said finally, "I have several questions. First, why are only women being affected by this revelation process? Second, what exactly are we supposed to do with seventy-two hours to prepare for an invasion by creatures that apparently devour light itself? And third, why do I get the feeling that an infinite stapler and a crash course in wing management aren't going to be sufficient preparation for whatever's coming?"

Sarah manipulated the viewing focus to display what appeared to be a complex organizational chart showing different types of supernatural beings and their roles in the original society they'd fled. "Only women are being revealed because in our original society, females were the warriors, protectors, and wielders of active mystical power. Males served primarily as support personnel, record keepers, and what you might call civilian infrastructure. The concealment network was designed to hide the females more deeply because they were the primary targets of the Devourers."

Jerry felt a mixture of relief and disappointment as he realized that his lack of wings and mystical powers wasn't a personal failing but rather an indication that he'd originally been something like a supernatural accountant or librarian. "So what happened to the males who came through with the refugees? Are they still hidden, or are there going to be more revelations?"

"Males will begin manifesting their true abilities tomorrow," Sarah explained, "but the process will be different. Less dramatic physical changes, but enhanced mental capabilities, supernatural technical skills, and access to the knowledge archives that were smuggled out during the evacuation. You'll essentially become the strategic and logistical support network for the females who'll be doing the actual fighting."

Mrs. Chen, who had been listening to the entire conversation with the patient attention of someone accustomed to dealing with unusual tenant situations, cleared her throat diplomatically. "This is all very fascinating, but I think we need to focus on practical considerations. If we're preparing for some kind of supernatural war, we'll need to coordinate with other revealed beings, establish communication networks, and probably file the appropriate paperwork with local authorities. Also, there are going to be significant insurance implications for property damage caused by learning to use mystical powers in residential buildings."

Jerry looked around at the group that had assembled in Sarah's transformed apartment: his ex-girlfriend the warrior angel, his neighbor the accounting valkyrie, his mystical arms-bearing building mate, and his elderly landlord who apparently planned to handle the approaching apocalypse through proper administrative procedures. In his hands, the infinite stapler pulsed with warm blue light, and the holographic displays continued to show images of approaching shadow creatures that threatened everything he'd ever believed about reality.

"Right," Jerry said, making what felt like the most important decision of his life. "If we're going to save the world, we're going to need a plan, more information, and probably a lot more people who know what they're actually supposed to be doing. Sarah, can that viewing focus help us locate other revealed beings in the area? Because something tells me that four supernatural refugees and one very organized human aren't going to be enough to handle what's coming."

The holographic display shifted in response to Jerry's question, showing a map of their city with dozens of glowing points of light scattered across the metropolitan area. Each light pulsed with a different color and intensity, suggesting that the revealed beings possessed varying types and levels of mystical abilities. Some of the lights were clustered in what Jerry recognized as hospitals, schools, and other service-oriented locations, while others appeared to be isolated in residential areas where women were probably dealing with their transformations alone.

"We can find them," Sarah confirmed, "but reaching them and convincing them to work together is going to be challenging. Most of them are probably terrified, confused, and possibly in denial about what's happening to them. And we have less than three days to organize them into an effective defense force against enemies that destroyed our original civilization."

Jerry stood up, tucking the infinite stapler back into his pocket where it continued to radiate reassuring warmth. Outside Sarah's windows, he could see more winged figures moving through the night sky, and in the distance, the lights of emergency vehicles suggested that similar revelation scenes were playing out across the city. The world had changed irrevocably in the space of a few hours, and somehow Jerry found himself at the center of efforts to prepare for a war that most people didn't even know was coming.

"Then we'd better get started," he said, looking around at his unlikely team of supernatural beings and determined humans. "Because if tonight has taught me anything, it's that the impossible has a tendency to become inevitable faster than anyone expects."

**Chapter 3**

The first challenge in organizing a supernatural defense network, Jerry discovered, was that most newly revealed beings had no idea how to use their cell phones with wings, extra arms, or other mystical appendages that hadn't existed during the design phase of modern technology. This became apparent when Sarah attempted to contact the closest cluster of lights on her holographic map, only to realize that her six-armed coordination was perfectly suited for manipulating mystical energies but terrible for operating devices designed for standard human anatomy. After watching her accidentally activate what appeared to be every app on her phone simultaneously, Jerry volunteered to handle the more mundane aspects of communication while the others focused on supernatural logistics.

"We need to establish a meeting point," Sheila said, her wings unconsciously spreading as she considered the tactical implications of their situation. "Somewhere large enough to accommodate people who might have significant physical changes, but also private enough that we won't attract unwanted attention from authorities who aren't ready to deal with supernatural refugees preparing for interdimensional war." She paused, her enhanced senses apparently picking up something from the ongoing emergency response outside their building. "Also, somewhere that isn't currently surrounded by police and fire departments trying to figure out why half the city's women have sprouted wings."
